reviews.review_msg: Such a good prof, he really makes what could be super hard material easy to understand! Makes lectures interesting & easy to follow!
This course is not easy and requires a lot of work but Pete makes this course very enjoyable.

PRetty tough course but if you put your time into it you can manage at least a B. As far as Pete goes, he Is the best professor ive taken so far at sfu. Brilliant professor who keeps class very interesting with his stories especially the ones from wrestling. Id come to this class pretty hung over and i managed a B, but i studied hard. SICK GUY!!

Awesome prof. Very clear explanations and keeps a difficult course interesting. Bring a laptop to lecture if you can because it is NONSTOP notes. He's also super cool and tells funny stories every class. Definitely recommend!

THIS IS THE COOLEST PERSON YOU WILL EVER MEET... hes super nice and makes a difficult course fathomable. I encourage anyone who has the opportunity to take a class with him to take it. The man is super smart, chill, and inspiring. this is the man

Pete is the best teacher I've had at SFU. He is passionate about the material and he incorporates entertaining examples to support his teachings. His notes are incredible...o and he allows a cheat sheet for the midterm/final. It is a super tough course but incredibly interesting!!!
Best. Prof. Ever. He makes criminal law so interesting. A lot of note taking, but totally worth it.
Very knowledgeable and well versed in criminal law. His lectures are 2 hours of straight note taking. Learned alot from him this semester. His exams are quite difficult and time constrained.

Very clear and precise. LOTS of notes and lots of memorization, but it's fairly interesting. He gives lots of example cases to help. Midterm only counts if you do worse on the final. No papers, just two exams and tutorial.

Fall 2021 he would not record lectures, this made it difficult to keep up cuz the lectures are long and dense. The tutorial participation/project are easy to get a good grade on. The memos take a lot of time but are fairly straight forward if you have good lecture notes. The final is ridiculous, it is so insanely long and you will run out of time

Dr. Fehr has an incredibly impressive background and his lectures were even better because of that. He was able to bring the material to life with real examples and his experiences as a lawyer. The course material itself can be quite dense and at times hard to grasp but going to office hours seriously makes all the difference in this class.

THIS PROF IS BY FAR THE WORST PROF I'VE EVER HAD. What he expects from students is ridiculously unrealistic and the amount of time given for exams makes it nearly impossible to finish. I genuinely do not understand how he has any good ratings. DO NOT take this class with him ABORT AT ALL COSTS!!!

The course in general was okay. However, the final exam was beyond unreasonable. For the two previous assignments we were given weeks notice to work on it. For the final exam that contained nearly twice the amount of work we only had 3 hrs plus an essay. Felt impossible to finish.

Had him online for Fall 2020, lectures were mandatory because he didn't do recordings to encourage attendance, posts slides before the lecture.. But his lectures are really good at summarizing the textbook material and cites cases that will help you for the memos, as well he will give hints on what cases/statutes to focus on for memos/final.

Colton is extremely knowledgeable at his subject, which allows a very in-depth course. The only problem that I found was that sometimes it is hard to catch everything he says, as he sometimes goes over topics quickly if nobody has questions. I would suggest having the pp notes ready beforehand and just add the extra things he mentions.

Professor Fehr is extremely knowledgeable and truly cares about his students. Attending his office hours is helpful as he is more than willing to point you in the right direction. If youre passionate about the law and constitutional issues, you will enjoy Fehrs engaging and thought-provoking lectures.

It was his first time teaching at SFU and he honestly taught very well and was resourceful and accessible. Content was heavy but he explained it well in lectures and gave examples. Pay attention to lectures because he will give clues about assignments and exams. Listen to every detail and focus on every point in the criteria and go to office hours!

Tamara was a fantastic professor! She's very accommodating if have a disability. You can really tell she cares about the success of her students. She is enthusiastic and passionate about what she teaches so her lectures are engaging. Feedback from the TA is helpful. Fun class if you like law. 10/10 for me.

Dr. O'Doherty was amazing! She made the class fun and engaging with weekly highlights lectures to make sure you understand the material. Also, the assignments are straightforward and easy to do well on if you take the time to do it. Overall amazing class and a great professor. Definitely recommend taking this class with her!

Class was 'self directed' so what is the point of paying so much? Lectures were 15 mins long and exams were form book and nothing form what she posts. Memo 1 was unclear, lost majority of points there. Expects so much and teaches so less, the most difficult class ever! I never want to study such a course again, I would rather change my major.

Amazing professor who lays out everything that is expected clearly. Exams were open book and Q&A sessions were held before all exams and assignments. Also offered a syllabus quiz where, if taken, allowed a 48 hour extension on any assignment

Dr. O'Doherty was absent outside of zoom calls. Grading was clear, but assignment instructions were difficult to understand. Wrote my first memo and had no idea what to do, minimal explanation. TA's didn't knock marks for it being your first ever memo though. Exams were easy, take your own notes and prepare! Exam 3hrs long, in sections!
Tamara was a very kind professor who made the assignments easy to follow. The class had long chapters to read each week, but weekly work was minimal. Very interesting and comprehensive course.

I loved her, she is so nice and helpful. You can tell she wants her students to do well. Keep up with the readings. Her lecture videos were helpful and the assignments were not hard. I hope I get to take her classes again.

Took CRIM 230 online and was really scared when looking at the marks breakdown, but, upon actually taking the class Tamara made the class easy to follow and was very helpful if you emailed about an assignment or wanted clarification was very accessible. Tamara holds office hours prior to major grading components (exams and assignments).
No lectures, and unclear guidelines.
Doesn't post any lectures so you have to self teach. Horrible exams; so difficult! (I did really well in 135 too). Would not recommend unless you want your gpa to drop.

Tamara is the most knowledgeable and kind professor we have in the crim department. Not only is she an amazing professor, but she teaches the lecture material in a way that is easy to grasp and helps you learn to have a critical eye. Her classes are not easy per say, but if you put in the work, you will be rewarded.
Pretty Hard for a second year course. The TA saved all the students from failing. Needed to use entire time for exams.

I took crim230 online and luckily, I had an amazing TM who made the class super enjoyable. The modules were really organized and made studying so easy. The midterm is take-home and the assignments help you prepare for the final. Study the cases that are outlined in the modules to do well on the final! Super fun class to take online.
Went way to fast over slides so you cannot get anything down, does not post slides.
LOVE HER

Definitely one of my favourite professors. She does fly through lecture slides at a faster than average pace, but if you pay attention it really isn't a problem (plus she posts all her lectures in canvas beforehand). Keeps her lectures interesting and links material to current events. The class is definitely tough and heavy on readings, but do-able
Great prof, amazing lectures, exams were fair but get ready to read!

She's an engaging prof, but if you're just looking for an easy A, not the prof to take. She goes through slides way too fast, but does touch on interesting topics which is always a good discussion. I probably wouldn't take her again because of her exams, they're super hard, but she herself is a sweet person.
she nice! i like!

Karm is a stellar teaching assistant; she makes every effort possible to help her students, and her warm personality is very comforting when you find yourself lost in the material. Further to this, her tutorials are informative, and she does a great job of engaging the class without singling anybody out.
She was really nice and very knowledgeable about the topic.

Oh my god, Amy is the worst professor I have ever had. Her slides are unhelpful so you need to follow along with her voice, but then she speaks really fast, and she loses her train of thought and you have no idea what is going on anymore. She teaches from the textbook, so read it or you won't get anything, and its as if she wants you to fail!!!

so hard to do well in this class as instructions are vague and you never know what she actually wants. grading is so harsh. also, we do not get the assignments back to look at our individual feedback, but we get “general feedback” which is not helpful. almost seems like she wants us to do poorly.

The class is basically self-taught through the textbook. You dont get much out of lectures since they dont teach anything, and instead are short summaries of long readings. Instructions are vague, and youre left guessing what she actually wants. also it doesnt help that shes a tough grader - so take at your own risk!

Oh man, I already regret taking CRIM230 and it hasn't been a month. Take this course with anyone else, and you'll do fine. Extremely tough grader, instructions and expectations are never clear, lectures are practically useless and you're expected to teach yourself through the textbook.

Worst prof to ever exist. Take the class with someone else. She will never be happy with your work, even if you go above and beyond because she won't tell you what she wants. Unless ur a psychic that can predict what she wants, go with another prof.

Taking crim230 with her currently. Honestly, she seems sweet but her teaching style isn't the best. It's clear that we need to read everything in the textbook. Lecture slides aren't helpful at all. Seems like I need to teach myself this course because Conroy doesn't make sense.

Amy is clearly passionate about both the subject and teaching. Success is determined by keeping up w lecture and regularly reviewing as it is content heavy. I treated the course like a 100 level crim class and failed the midterm. After putting in a bit more effort and attending TA/prof office hours i was able to get a 91 on the final.
So difficult to pass

Would not recommend. She was never on time, and lectures weren't helpful at all. The entire course is taught by the textbook. Her voice is very high pitched yet hoarse, and VERY LOUD, making it hard to listen to lectures.

Amy has NEVER been on time for a single lecture, even for the midterm, which took more time away from the in-class assignments that were extremely rushed to begin with. She doesn't give clear instructions or examples of how she wants us to do things so good luck with the memos. Doesn't give specific feedback so you'll never know what you did wrong!

I have never disliked a professor as much as Amy Conroy in my 3 years at SFU. She has ruined my spark for crim, and the reason I switched out of the program. In lectures she just yaps about everything and nothing all at once. She makes no sense. She doesn't teach and expects us to read the entire textbook from front to back and learn ourselves.
According to Amy I should have started studying the material as soon as I exited the womb

Amy Conroy is the bane of my existence. Girlie just rambles on forever about how we need to know everything related to criminal law and then gives us maybe 20 minutes to scramble and write an in-class assignment worth 20% of our grade. Always shows up late and starts late too! I feel like I am a 7-year-old being lectured by my mom every time I go.

Amy has such a clear passion which made the difficult content easier to digest. Ive never done a rating here but I wanted to express how much she bettered my experience. Her slides dont include the full content, so going to class is very helpful (she does post audio recordings). She explains very clearly and has clear criteria for assignments.
I liked her. I think if you are engaged with her lectures they make sense and she explains things pretty well. The grading is tough in this class though for all of the assignments and exams.

Understand how ppl think shes a tough grader but I also think its because the course material is difficult in itself & requires students to put in the work. I enjoyed this class because of the interesting course content but the lectures are pretty useless, textbook is much more important. Shes very clear on what it takes to do well in her course

I don't know why there are so many negative comments about Amy. From the beginning she said we needed to read all the chapters in order to do good and she gave very clear instructions for the midterm and final. Don't hate on the prof if you are just not willing to read and to the bare minimum for a challenging class.

Amy sucks I genuinely had like 5 mental breakdowns over this class. Her lectures are just her ranting for 2 hours and her slides have no information on them. She tries to start discussions in lectures but nobody speaks because everyone is probably asleep from her tangents. All her content is heavily based on the textbook so make sure you read it

Amy made a 200 level course harder than it should have been. LOTS of readings, many real life cases from the textbook and she would not let us know which ones should be focused on. Slides were useless, lecture discussions often led to tangents.

I don't know why everyone seems to hate her. She is perfectly fine, good even. This course's assignments and exams were very reading focused, the lectures just highlighted things she was more likely to ask on exams etc. went into this course anxious because of the ratings, but it was perfectly fine. don't be scared. you'll do great.

Graeme is passionate about what he teaches and the concepts learned in class were interesting. 3 written assignments were tough but not impossible. Midterm and final were both open book but limited time for exams and he likes to do trick questions. Always recommend taking 135 or 230 with him. Great prof

Don't even bother with this professor. Just don't. Think you know criminal law? Think you will do fine? Think again. He has very high expectations, will not give you the rubric, and marks super hard. For a 200 level course, he makes it way too difficult. Save your gpa, save your mental it really is not worth it

insanely tough course for a 200 level. has insane expectations without giving the rubric. TA is actually crazy because they do not help, nor do they know what is going on; every mark you get back will BREAK you and your GPA. DO NOT TAKE HIM BECAUSE HE WILL FAIL YOU.

don't. take. this. guy. first assignment will BREAK you, they don't explain anything nor give u feedback. they don't even give you a RUBRIC. TA's are questionable and have no idea what to do, will teach u things verbally but not physically teach you how to format. midterm (no time, too strict, avg was 50-57% and said he was happy) 5/10. exam? hard.

Professor Bowbrick is intelligent and his lectures go through the criminal code well. However, it is very difficult to succeed in his course. He does not provide feedback and when he does, it is in person so you won't be able to record down any notes he has. His TAs are questionable, and you basically have to read his mind to get a good mark.

Graeme is not an easy prof, you have to work for a good grade in this course. That being said, I would 100% recommend taking any course you can with him. He is hilarious, and makes the material memorable and easy to understand. He expects a lot from his students but his passion for the material makes you interested in it. One of my favorite profs!

Honestly the most inspirational, as well as the hardest professor I've ever had. He really makes you work for your grade but it pays off and you WILL learn, and won't take anything half-assed. I'm glad I have the chance to have him again in 330 because I've honestly changed a lot of how I think about things because of him.

He's a great lecturer and definitely knows the law in and out; however, he expects a lot for a lower division class. He does not let you bring the pocket criminal code into exams (unlike other Crim 230 classes) and makes you memorize the codes. He also has somewhat of an attitude problem, where he almost seems confrontational in office hours.

Graeme is a very good lecturer. In addition to this, it is consistent that if you do take his class, you probably won't need the textbook, which is awesome as it is lecture heavy. However, I feel Graeme expects a heck of a lot more than the average prof at SFU. I deem this unfair for lower div classes as students will often take a huge GPA hit.

Loved this class. Graeme is a really great lecturer and the class was incredibly interesting.  Make sure to read the textbook before classes!  You definitely need to study for the tests (which are mostly writing-focused) but if you do then it'll be fine.  Participation in tutorials also mandatory but tutorials were also interesting.

He''s a really good professor if you''re there to learn the material. If you''re looking for an easy A though then he''s not the prof you''re looking for. His exams are very fair but he marks very hard on the fact patterns. Everything is lecture based so if you show up and take notes you''ll pass but he makes you REALLY work for an A.

I had the chance to have Rebecca as a professor for several classes and honestly she's one of the best teachers I ever had! She not only made the course material interesting and easy to understand, but she also went out of her way to help me and make sure I understood what was expected of me. Would definitely recommend taking her classes!!

Most of the profs I've had usually sick to lecturing the course material from the textbook. While Rebecca incorporates real life examples. Upon which is further analysed by classroom discussion. She is very approachable, marks fair, and provides feedback where she would like you to elaborate more. Would definitely recommend taking her class.

Pam is a great professor. One of the best in the criminology department. She understands the needs of her students and is available to help students with assignments and course materials. Pam has clear grading components and tells you what you need to know for the exam. Take every class you can with Pam.

Pamela is an amazing instructor. She is very passionate and very helpful. She is also super relatable and puts in a lot of effort to help students succeed and have an enjoyable time in the class. I would 100% take her again.
One of the best professors Ive had at SFU. Passionate about what she teaches. Shes understanding for student problems and has a very interesting lectures and assignments.

Pam must be the best professor I've met at SFU so far. She really puts lots of effort into teaching to make sure you understand the material and enjoy learning. She wants students to succeed and provides an engaging class. The assignments are fun and require deep thoughts and critical analysis; which is a chance to share your thoughts!
A nice person but the creative assignment was a bit vague on the criteria.

Pam is one of the most creative professors I have had the privilege of being taught by. Her lectures are designed in a way that relates and conforms to society currently. She is also very personable and understands the struggles that students go through. She also allows time for students to ask questions regarding exams, assignments, etc.

Pamla has been by far the most down to earth and caring prof I have ever had at SFU. She uses her own experiences as a student during her undergrad to teach better and to ensure students don't have the same miss-haps she did when she was in university. I would Strongly recommend Pamela as she is a gem that accurately relates to students today.
She literally makes learning about murderers fun and simple ahah. Loved the class :)

Pam is the best prof I have ever & will ever have! She is incredibly kind, caring, & reasonable. She creates an environment by how she teaches that engages with the class, which allows for the material to be understood easily, & it made the course incredibly enjoyable. She does not teach like it is simply her job but instead with true passion.

Pam is the best prof I've ever had. She gets to know her students and truly cares for them. Her assignments and response paper are fun and easier than research papers. She values students and their mental health and will happily help you if you reach out. She truly cares and I look forward to future classes she teaches.

Iryna is one of the most caring and passionate proffessors you can have. She challenges you in a very effective way to excercise critical thought and your own mind. She may be more difficult than some professors, but she compensates with willingness to help students. You will always get out the effort you put into her classes.

Criminal Law class is pretty hard, but Iryna really tries to help her students. Attend lectures, tutorials and office hours, read the textbook - and you will be fine. I promise that you won't regret taking this class with her!

Iryna is a very nice lady, but unfortunately her lectures left a bit to be desired. She spent about half of her lectures reading from her slides from the previous lecture which may sound helpful, but it proved to be otherwise. When she got into the new material it was rushed and not particularly well put together.

Helene was quite a hard marker, but overall a decently fair professor. LOTS of content. The time constraints for the exams were difficult, and the final was a bit ill-organized but she compensated fairly afterward. A harder class, but Helene as a professor was okay. Nothing to be afraid of, but definitely not an easy A class.

Took 135 with her in person and really struggled due to the amount of cases/statutes youre expected to remember, but 230 online was substantially easier since open book. If you have to take 135/230 with her, definitely take it remote or youll suffer trying to memorize the entire book

The course content itself is difficult (lots of reading!) but she explains things well. She is easy to talk to in office hours and gives good advice when its one-on-one. Not much time to complete online exams, but manageable if you dont fall behind and study hard.

I personally wouldn't want to take any classes with her because she's too dry in her lectures, but she's an alright prof. There's in class group discussion every week which is kinda awkward, but it helps us engage with other students and retain some materials. Make good use of the tutorial if you feel that you don't understand the lecture

I wish her slides were more detailed. The exam questions are difficult; even though questions did not explicitly state to, I did well by throwing down as much information I knew on simple questions because it was implicitly expected. Otherwise great prof, super passionate & caring - just be prepared to do a lot of heavy lifting in this course.

Easy to follow, likeable. Issues: doesn't allocate enough time to complete exams. Idk why she always references 'one minute per question' when half of her questions are written - expecting definitions, C.C. references, Statue references, opinion, likelihood of conviction, etc. It takes me over a minute just to read the question in front of me.
